layer_1_whats_happening.who_tells_it: An all-knowing narrator who constantly comments and guides us, taking the children's side against unfair adults.
layer_1_whats_happening.what_we_experience: We follow a brilliant girl who uses her intelligence and magical powers to defeat cruel adults and find a loving home.
layer_1_whats_happening.how_it_feels: We feel conspiratorial with the narrator, laughing at ridiculous adults while cheering for Matilda's victories.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Adults are hilariously blind to their own children's faults and Matilda's brilliance, setting up a world where grown-ups can't be trusted to see clearly.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: the most disgusting little blister you could ever imagine
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Hyperbole makes everything absurdly exaggerated to mock parental delusion, while vivid imagery creates Miss Trunchbull as a physically threatening presence.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Children must warn and protect each other because the school system is run by a genuinely dangerous tyrant who uses physical violence.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: she simply picked him up by one arm and flung him clear out
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Dialogue between children reveals the systematic abuse, while direct characterization establishes Miss Trunchbull's Olympic background as a real threat.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Matilda's supernatural powers represent how exceptional intelligence can become a force that challenges and defeats oppressive systems.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: I can push them over, and bigger things too, much bigger things
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Symbolism turns her abilities into representations of intellectual power, while the motif of burning eyes shows power building physically.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Intelligence works strategically and secretly, planning carefully before striking against injustice.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: Let me make sure I've got them right
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Dramatic irony lets us sense Matilda's secret plan while suspense builds toward the confrontation, and verbal irony hides her true intentions.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Children can choose their own families when biological families fail them, and true belonging comes from love rather than blood.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: Spain! I don't want to go to Spain! I love it here and I love my school!
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Stream of consciousness shows Matilda's panic, while internal monologue reveals Miss Honey's protective understanding of the crisis.

layer_3_connections.step_1: The all-knowing narrator lets us see inside everyone's thoughts while constantly commenting to build solidarity between reader and child against foolish adults.
layer_3_connections.step_2: The conspiratorial, child-championing tone makes us feel like we're part of a secret rebellion, laughing at adult incompetence while supporting Matilda's intelligence.
layer_3_connections.step_3: Together: we experience the story as fellow conspirators in a child's righteous war against unfair authority, making her victory feel like our victory too.
layer_3_connections.pattern_explanation: The narrator intrudes constantly to advocate for children's rights and guide us toward supporting Matilda's rebellion.

components.what_they_reveal: the systematic failures of adult authority
components.larger_meaning: children's right to choose loving families over biological ones
components.method: through conspiratorial humor that makes readers allies in the fight

layer_4_thesis.thesis_sentence: Through an all-knowing, child-championing narrator who reveals the systematic failures of adult authority, Dahl creates a magical rebellion story that argues for children's right to choose loving families over biological ones, using conspiratorial humor that makes readers allies in the fight against unfair power.
